metadata.title: Expo + Native: An Unexpected Bromance?
metadata.summary: Expo is no longer just for small apps or beginners‚Äîits limitations are now the exception. With tools like Expo Router v5 and the Expo Modules API, you can keep the Expo workflow while unlocking native power, collaborating with native devs, and building hybrid apps without ejecting.
metadata.author: Louis Place

data.title: The Evolution of Expo
data.content: For a long time, people thought Expo was only for small apps or beginner developers. But that paradigm is now outdated: limitations have become the exception, not the rule.

data.text: üí° Even though Expo Core provides powerful and mature tools‚Äîlike the brand new **Expo Router v5**, which I find particularly impressive‚Äîsometimes you need access to platform-specific native features: iOS widgets, system sensors, advanced audio modules‚Ä¶
üß© That's exactly what I experienced a year ago, when integrating an iOS widget into an app for a client. At the time, I discovered you can avoid "ejecting" the project!

üëâ Thanks to the **Expo Modules API**, I was able to create a local native module in Swift, cleanly integrated into an Expo project with the Dev Client. The result: I kept all the benefits of the Expo workflow (cross-platform, EAS Build, top-notch DX) while accessing full native power.

data.title: üìú A bit of history:
data.content: The Expo Modules API was introduced in July 2021 with Expo SDK 42. With the stable release of EAS Build in 2022, the framework took a major turn: this API lets you write native code via Dev Client without ejecting‚Äîwhich used to be the only option for custom native code.
